SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A LIST OF QUESTIONNAIRES TO THE PERSONS WHO ANSWERED THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions herein will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The object of this questionnaire is not to collect facts but to give an idea of what life was like in the past.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pilot: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Really Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and are willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Later data. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Provincial Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

A LIST OF QUESTIONS TO THE PERSON

REPORTED THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire to pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The questions are in order of their importance, but not necessarily in order of the events they illustrate. If there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Lists: What Did Saskatchewan Pioneers Entertain?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

Preservation of Questionnaires

My mother kept a diary corresponding about from 3-4 weeks.

I was married to Mr. Smith on June 15th, 1913.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

We traveled about 60 miles by wagon, back road or stage coach. We knew how to drive for the above reasons. From 6-10 miles via dirt roads, 30 miles via friends near Hudson Bay, about 12 miles to Red Deer, Alta., or Kootenay City, B.C., about 100 miles to Yorkton or St. Albert for supplies.

We traveled about 600 miles by wagon back trail or stagecoach. We knew by hearsay for the above reasons. From 6-10 miles. Visited family, 30 miles & visit friends in Idaho. About 15 miles to Newell's also a relative living off Idaho. About 100 miles to Yorkton or the Appalachee for shopping. Work on getting some annual supplies - flour, sugar, and general provisions.
